title: Srimad bhagavatam 2.9.33 Lecture-3 by HG Stoka Krishna Prabhu
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: and that he is a person. The predominated I, Brahma, is also a person, but he is not absolute.
For realization of oneself in spiritual psychology, it may be convenient to assume oneself to be the same principle as the absolute truth,
but there is always the difference of the predominated and the predominator,
as clearly pointed out here in this verse, which is grossly misused by the impersonalists.
Brahma is the fact he is actually seen face to face, his predominated Lord,
who exists in his transcendental eternal form even after the annihilation of the material creation.
The form of the Lord, as seen by Brahma, existed before the creation of Brahma,
and a material manifestation with all the invocations.
The ingredients and agents of the material creation are also energetic expansions of the Lord.
And after the exhibition of the Lord's energy comes to a close, what remains is the same personality of Godhead.
Therefore, the form of the Lord exists in all circumstances of creation, maintenance, and annihilation.
The Vedic hymns confirm this fact in the statement,
Vāsute govā idaṁ agra-āsim na brahma na caśankarā
eko nārāyaṇa-hāsim na brahma na caśankarā
Before the creation, there was none except Vāsudeva, there was neither Brahma nor Śaṅkara.
Only Nārāyaṇa was there and no one else, neither Brahma nor Caśankara.
Śrīpāda Śaṅkārya also confirms in his comments on the Bhagavad-gītā
that Nārāyaṇa, or the personality of Godhead, is transcendental to all creation,
but that the whole creation is the product of Avyaktā.
Therefore, the difference between the creator and the under-creator is always there,
although both the creator and the under-creator are of the same quality.
So that's the third parā-lāha purport.
om ajñāna-tivirāṁ tasya jñānāṁ janśalākaya
cakṣa-numīritaṁ jena tasmaiṁ śrī-gudale namaḥ
nama'oṁ viṣma-vādāyāḥ kṛṣṇa-kṛṣṇaya-bhuttale
śrī-malai-vakti-velaṁ tasmā
nityadāmiṇi
namaste sārasvaṅgadevaya-gauravāṇi-kacāriṇi
nirviśeṣa-śaṁnavādi-pāścārya-kariśukāriṇi
jaya śrī-kṛṣṇa-cetanya-pravṛta-vāñilā
śrī-advaita-gadādala-śrī-valāśādhi-dodavaktarila
Hare Kṛṣṇa Hare Kṛṣṇa Kṛṣṇa Kṛṣṇa Hare Hare
Hare Rāma Hare Rāma Rāma Rāma Hare Hare
So as I was explaining yesterday
The truth about Krishna or the personality of God or Supreme person
is being explained in the Bhagavatam very elaborately
and particularly
in these four verses called the Tushloki Bhagavata, this particular fact is explained that the
Absolute Truth is the Supreme Person.
Now, Prabhupada is trying to explain in the purport that this personality of Godhead in front of Brahma is not an ordinary person like you and me.
He is a completely transcendental personality.
And what is the reason to say he is a transcendental person?
He is not a person like me. He is a creative person.
So the arguments or the explanations are supported in so many ways.
One of the ways is to go by the verse itself.
You see the context of this verse.
Brahma has been created. A Brahma is born.
He doesn't know the source of his birth.
And he gets an instruction that he has to perform tapasya.
He hears the two letters ta and pa.
And his intelligence,
he utilizes and understands that he has to perform tapasya.
He performs tapasya.
And as a result of his performing tapasya, he has darshan of, he gets to see Vishnu.
And after seeing Vishnu, he understands or is able to directly see,
Oh, Vishnu is the source of my birth.
And then he asks certain questions to Vishnu.
And Vishnu is giving the reply.
Now when Vishnu is giving the reply to Brahma,
obviously, Vishnu being the source of Brahma,
his answers to Brahma are authoritative.
You have to accept the authority of Vishnu,
who is replying to Brahma.
After Brahma has tried to find the source of his birth,
being unable to find, he performs tapasya.
And as a result of tapasya, he has become enlightened.
And he is now able to see the source of his birth.
And then hear from Vishnu,
the source about who is Vishnu.
Therefore, Prabhupada says in the purport here,
in another feature of this verse,
no one can deny the personalities of both the Lord and Brahma.
That Brahma as a person is standing in front of Vishnu.
And Vishnu is present in front of Brahma as a person.
That is confirmed in this verse itself.
That the personality of Vishnu and Brahma cannot be denied.
Now, their personality is spiritual,
or at least the God's personality is spiritual.
He is clearly explained in the Kathopanishad verse,
which is quoted by Prabhupada,
whether we have a material form or not.
In any case, according to the Kathopanishad verse,
there are eternal conscious beings.
And there are two categories,
singular and plural.
So in the previous paragraph,
Prabhupada had explained
that there is a difference between these two categories,
because even though the similarity is nitya and cetana,
the difference is,
the singular is actually maintaining the plural.
So that singular is the Supreme Lord.
And the maintained are the living entities.
It is very clear from the verse of the Kathopanishad.
And that is corroborated here,
that in the ultimate issue,
both the predominator and predominated are persons.
Predominator is the Lord,
who is the maintainer.
And the maintained are the predominated,
as is evident from Rama,
Rama's own position.
Now the impersonalists, they say,
whatever personality is being referred in this verse,
or whatever we experience in this world,
all these personalities are temporary manifestations,
temporary forms.
But we cannot accept Vishnu's form as temporary,
for the simple reason that form existed before the creation,
remains during the creation,
and continues to exist even after everything is destroyed.
If Vishnu's form existed before the creation,
remains during the duration of the whole creation.
And as it is, it is there in that directly described.
That form is not a material form.
That is an eternal form.
And we know, anything which is eternal cannot be material.
From the Bhagavad Gita, from all the Upanishads,
from the Vedas, we understand,
matter does not endure,
and spirit never ceases to exist.
Na sato vidyate bhavo, na bhavo vidyate sata.
Very, very clear.
Since Vishnu's form is eternally existing,
Vishnu's form is necessarily a spiritual form.
Vishnu formed spiritually.
If Vishnu's form is a spiritual form,
and we are also in quality same as Vishnu,
we are also nitya and chetana.
But our relationship for our position means we are maintained by
the singular nitya and chetana.
Then it becomes very clear that
Vishnu is the single maintainer,
eternal, conscious person.
And we are the maintained, eternal, conscious persons.
We are many.
Because there is only one Supreme God
and there are many living entities.
So therefore, the impersonal stress,
impersonal features stressed by the less intelligent impersonal list,
is refuted
by pointing out
that Vishnu,
who is the creator of Brahma,
who existed before the creation,
who remains after the destruction of the entire universe,
is a person.
If that entity who remains before
creation or after destruction
is a person,
then ultimately the absolute within person is refuted.
Now for realization of one's own self,
if one thinks
I am equal to God
in terms of quality,
then that is helpful, it is conducive
to separate ourselves from the ahamkara that I am matter
or I am this material body,
which is very, very
strong,
strong feeling
or big misunderstanding
that is there in every person's
consciousness.
What is the greatest misunderstanding that exists in this world?
Everything sees the body.
So,
to convince
anybody interested in self-realization,
to convince that person
that you are not the body, you are not matter,
it is stressed
in the Upanishads
that you are one in quality with the Lord
or the Absolute Truth,
who is completely spiritual.
So Prabhupada says,
for the realization of one's self in spiritual psychology,
it may be convenient to assume one's self
with the same principle as the Absolute Truth.
It is just a matter of convenience.
But I am same as the body.
I am equal to the Lord.
It is a matter of convenience.
But there is always the difference
of the predominated and the predominator.
Vishnu or God,
the Absolute Truth,
is always the predominator,
always the dominator,
always the maintainer,
always the Lord,
always the controller,
always the master.
And I,
or any living being for that matter,
or even Brahma,
is always about that,
always controlled,
always maintained,
always subordinate.
It is very, very clear.
Now Brahma is actually seeing face to face
the predominated Lord
who exists in this transcendental eternal form
even after the annihilation of the material creation.
We know after the whole universe is destroyed,
creation is destroyed,
nothing material in form will remain.
No material form will remain.
Including Brahma,
Brahma will not remain.
That we know from the scriptures.
So if nothing material remains
after everything is destroyed,
and if Vishnu remains,
and he has got a form,
and he has got a form,
then what is the conclusion?
Vishnu's form is spiritual.
Vishnu's form is eternal.
Vishnu's form is non-material.
So therefore,
the form seen by Brahma
is a transcendental form,
spiritual form.
And,
this entire material world which we see
is a manifestation of the energy
of that Supreme Person.
Because He has multifarious energies
as explained in the Upanishads
and all the other scriptures.
And His energies are manifesting different varieties,
especially in this material world.
So those varieties are made of
the energy.
And the Lord remains
the source of that energy,
the basis of that manifestation.
So therefore,
as confirmed in the Vedas also,
the Vedas have confirmed in the statement
that
vāsute govā idaṁ agra āsīt
This is the very statement.
Now the same thing Krishna has done in
ahaṁ evāsaṁ evāgre
I existed
before the creation.
And same thing is told in the Vedas,
vāsute govā idaṁ agra āsīt
Vāsudeva existed before the creation.
na brahma na ca śāntara
Brahmā and Śiva did not exist.
Another statement,
nārāyaṇa āsī na brahmādeśāna
Nārāyaṇa existed before the creation,
but Brahmā and Śiva did not exist.
So,
before the creation there was none
except Vāsudeva and Nārāyaṇa.
Only Nārāyaṇa was there and no one else.
And Cangaracharya in his commentary on the Bhagavad Gita,
what does he say?
He says that
nārāyaṇa paro avyattāt
It's a bit of Cangaracharya in the Bhagavad Gita.
Cangaracharya is an impersonalist.
But he says in the Bhagavad Gita,
in the beginning,
in the commentary in the Bhagavad Gita,
nārāyaṇa is transcendental,
to this material creation.
Because the material creation is coming from avyattāt.
Before this creation, what was there?
Material energy in the unmanifest form.
So then the unmanifest form became manifested
as first the ingredients
and those ingredients were added upon by the
three gunas
and then the variety was produced.
Therefore in the scriptures it is said
sat and asat, which is described in this verse,
cause and effect.
Sorry, effect and cause.
Sat is the effect, asat is the cause.
The material creation which is produced
at the beginning of the creation,
whatever is produced,
the cause is material nature itself.
Everything is a product of material nature.
But the cause itself is material nature.
The cause itself is material nature.
So both the cause and effect are material.
But still, transcendental to this cause and effect,
sat asat param,
is Viṣṇu and nārāyaṇa,
or the personality of God.
He is transcendental both to cause and effect of this material.
So elsewhere it is explained
that material nature is working
to produce a transformation
or to combine the different elements
or to create or maintain or destroy
according to the direction of Krishna.
So if Krishna is directing,
how is He directing?
He is directing through the directors
of the gunas,
called the guna avatāras.
Through Brahma, He is directing.
I explained this elaborately in a previous class.
Through Brahma, He is directing rajo guna.
Through Viṣṇu, He is directing the sattva guna.
And through Śrīma, He is directing the buddha.
But it is He only who is directing
because He is sitting on the heart of Brahma,
the heart of Brahma as the super-soul.
He himself expanded as Viṣṇu.
And Śiva also is receiving direction
from Viṣṇu or nārāyaṇa.
So therefore, ultimately,
even though material nature is immediate cause
of this creation
and different changes in material nature,
even though above the gunas,
material nature as gunas is acting,
above the gunas are the directors,
even beyond the directors is Krishna.
Beyond the directors is Krishna.
So ultimately, Krishna is the cause of all causes.
He is the ultimate controller of all controllers.
Therefore, in the Brahma Samhita,
He said,
Īśvaraḥ paramaṁ viṣṇahāṁ
sarva-kāraṇatāṁ
ultimate cause of all causes.
He is the controller of all controllers.
And that same thing is explained here
that nārāyaṇa is transcendent to all creation.
And the creation is the product of the abhyakta.
Abhyakta is a material energy in a manifest state.
It becomes manifested as a soul material.
So this is explained in Śaṅkara ārācārya.
And therefore, the difference between
the creator and the created always exists.
Both are part in all aspects.
Even though the living entities are
of the same quality as God,
the living entities are not equal to God in all respects
because the living entities are created by God
in terms of the living entities getting their material body.
As spirits only, they are not created.
But as living entities in this material world
who are getting different types of bodies,
they are all created.
As living entities who are taking birth in the material world,
they are all created.
So that creation is different from
the Lord giving darshan to Brahma
in his form.
Vishnu form, nārāyaṇa form, Kṛṣṇa form,
any transcendental forms.
So when the Lord gives darshan,
you cannot say,
Oh, he has taken birth now.
Even when he apparently takes birth,
as Kṛṣṇa or Rāma or Vāvana,
you cannot say he is born.
Because Bhagavad Gita what does it say?
ajopīsaṁ avyayātmā
It says when the transcendental body
never deteriorates,
avyayātmā
Avyayātmā means that it does not deteriorate.
And ajara, he is unborn.
Even though he is unborn
and his transcendental body never deteriorates,
but still he appears.
Sambhavāmi ātmam āhyamā
What does that verse say?
ajopīsaṁ avyayātmā bhūtānāṁ īśvaropīsaṁ
He is the Lord of all created beings.
Bhūtā means that which is created.
We are all created beings.
Brahma is a created being.
All of us are created beings.
All demigods are created beings.
Everyone is created in this world.
So bhūtānāṁ īśvaropīsaṁ
Bhūtānāṁ īśvaropīsaṁ
He is the Lord.
But still Prakṛtim Svām
He has got a particular nature.
Prakṛtim Svām adiṣṭhāya sambhavāmi ātmam āhyamā
He has got a specific type of energy
which is called yoga māyā or ātma māyā.
And that māyā He employs for appearing in this world.
Sambhavāmi.
He appears to take birth or He comes in the form of incarnation
or He incarnates in this world.
Whatever way you describe that appearance of the Lord.
That is based on this understanding that
He always exists.
And He just employs His internal potency
for the sake of His incarnation or His pastimes
or His manifestation and so forth.
So this much is explained in this third part.
Any questions?
Do you have any questions?
Do you have any thoughts on nature like
the nature of Shiva?
The Mahārāja and Shiva.
But there are some other questions.
No.
They don't come under the modes.
By the grace of the Supreme Lord,
Brahmā, Vishnu and Shiva
don't come under the influence of the modes.
Though Brahmā and Shiva are subject to the influence.
They are subject to the influence because their position is such.
But by the Lord's mercy,
they don't come under the influence.
Only then they can do the work of directing.
If they themselves come under the modes,
then how can they direct?
They will not be able to direct.
Therefore,
by the grace of the Supreme Lord,
for the sake of direction,
they don't come under the modes.
But their position is not that
like Vishnu is above the modes,
constitutionally,
Brahmā and Shiva are not above the modes,
constitutionally.
They may come under the modes.
It happens sometimes.
But they have protection of Vishnu.
If Brahmā thought,
Krishna is an ordinary one.
And what did he do?
He stole away Krishna's thumb and covered it up.
So immediately Krishna corrected him.
And then Brahmā came and said,
Oh, it's too cute to do all that.
It's all right.
It's all right now.
Shiva thought,
Mohini Murthy is a beautiful, enjoyable woman.
Let me try to enjoy her.
And then he realized after he tried,
Oh, this is my girl.
It's not enjoyable for me.
Sometimes,
Raman and Shiva,
even though they may come under the influence of the gunas,
still,
for the sake of directing the gunas,
as directors of the modes,
they are protected against fallout or influence
by the grace of the Supreme Lord.
And that same thing applies for all of us.
If we have the mercy of the Supreme Lord,
we can expect that we will be protected by the Lord,
and we will not.
But we will not become entangled in mind with illusory energy.
Krishna says that in Bhagavad Gita,
māne vaye prapadyante māyā-meta karaniteta
Anybody who surrenders to Krishna
can cross over the influence of this illusory energy.
So Brahmā and Shiva are completely surrendered to Krishna.
So they are always protected.
They are always protected.
And constitutionally you can't say
that they are above the modes.
No.
Vishnu or Krishna or Narayana,
they are always above the modes
because they are the controllers.
Yes.
I will end it here.
And then for those who want to ask questions,
are there any questions?
Yes.
I do have a few questions.
There are a few questions related to this.
One is Shiva.
One is Veda.
What is Shiva?
What is Veda?
Veda is the Dharama which is the close connection between Krishna and Krishna.
This is Veda.
This is Veda.
When Shiva was in the house of Narsimha,
what was his position?
He was in the house of Narsimha.
Am I right?
functions which he performs as an incarnation of Vishnu. And certain functions he does as
a living being completely controlled and directed by Vishnu. So he's got this dual function because one
particular function of Shiva requires that he come in contact with the
material energy. Vishnu never comes in contact with material energy.
Vishnu always is the controller, director of material energy, but he never comes in contact.
So when there is a need for Vishnu to come in contact with the material energy,
for the sake of certain purposes in the material world,
then it is Shiva, who is another form of Vishnu,
who actually contacts the material energy and makes the creation possible.
So that form of the Lord, who is an expansion of Vishnu, for the sake of his material creation,
who comes in contact with the material energy is called Shiva.
Prabhupada says Shambhu principle. Shambhu principle is that he is simultaneously Vishnu and not Vishnu.
As the expansion of Vishnu, he is of the quality of Vishnu, of the stature of Vishnu.
For the sake of the creation, when he comes in contact with the material energy,
he is like a Jeeva.
So he is both.
Just like the example was given in the Brahma Samhita.
Yogurt, dahi, is same as milk and different from milk.
Because dahi, same as milk, is a product of milk only.
But still, dahi has got its own different quality than milk.
When it comes to the action of milk versus curds or yogurt,
you see, they have got different effect.
So that is because milk, when it comes in contact with some acid,
it turns into yogurt.
Milk transformed is yogurt.
So when milk is transformed into yogurt, you cannot say that yogurt is same as milk in all respects.
But then, what is the transformation that has happened?
It is milk only, in another form.
Milk only.
So, simultaneously, same as and different from.
That is Shiva's position.
Therefore, we say Shiva is not in Shiva.
Shiva is not Vishnu.
Shiva is in Milk only.
And it is for a specific purpose only.
Why Shiva is in an intermediate position, where Jeeva is not Vishnu.
He does both the functions.
Both kinds of functions he carries out.
Jeeva?
He didn't.
His material world, they are contacting the mind, the mind.
Seeks in the end.
That is another function.
The director of the mind.
That is another function.
The director of the mind.
He has to go out there.
Yeah, that is his teacher as same as Vishnu.
same as Vishnu. No, no, no. He exists even after the creation. He is our temporary office in this material world also.
Like wherever Shiva is, he is a Kailasa. There is a Kailasa in the spiritual world, there is a Kailasa in the material world.
He is difficult to understand Shiva's position because he has some attributes of Vishnu and some attributes of Jeeva
and he has got many different functions also that he performs.
It is like
it is like
a Jeeva contacts material energy.
Jeeva is subject to bewilderment by the material energy.
Therefore you see Shiva, when he contacts material energy,
to avoid bewilderment by the material energy, he engages in meditation on Sankarsana.
See picture of Shiva sitting with Rudraksha Mala.
He is meditating what he is doing in Japan.
On whom is he actually fixing his attention?
Fixing attention to Sankarsana, the Supreme God.
Why that?
Because when he contacts material energy, he is subject to bewilderment.
Just like when we chant Hare Krishna,
we can transcend the influence of the gudas.
That is the characteristic of Jeeva.
Jeeva, when he contacts material energy, he is subject to bewilderment.
But if a Jeeva wants to avoid bewilderment, what should a Jeeva do?
He should fix his attention on Krishna, Supreme God.
Similarly, when Shiva contacts material energy,
like a Jeeva, he is subject to bewilderment.
And therefore, he engages in devotional service.
That's why we have statements like,
Shiva is the greatest devotee.
Vaishnavana Mitashyam Bhur.
You see Shiva performing devotional service.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Shiva's feature as Vishnu.
That feature is distinctly different from Vishnu himself,
even though he shares some attributes,
he is not Vishnu.
Whereas Vaikuntha, Narayana or Vishnu is completely transcendental, eternally soul. He is always the master of the gunas but he never comes in contact with the gunas.
It is like Jeeva cannot create this material world and Vishnu never comes in contact with the material world even though he is the creator.
So the binary between Vishnu and the Jeeva is Shiva for the sake of creation.
It is a very specific necessity of this creation.
Creation is because of the interaction of the gunas producing the variety in the material energy, the presentation. That's what the creation is.
Because the creation is only there for some time, that's all.
Whereas whatever is manifested by Krishna's internal potency,
that's of a different quality,
that's also manifestation but of a different quality.
So that quality manifestation is different internal potency for Krishna's purposes, for a spiritual purpose.
Here the material energy presenting so many varieties by interaction of the gunas is for the bewilderment of the conditioned soul who wants to enjoy independent of the Lord.
So it is a very specific requirement.
It is a illusory presentation.
So this illusory presentation is made possible by Shiva.
Because even though the gunas are interacting,
the gunas cannot interact and produce the changes unless there is a touch of
spirit.
Matter cannot act by itself.
Matter has to be touched by spirit.
So that junction point where matter and spirit touch,
that is called ahamkara.
Like this body for example.
Now this body is matter.
I am spirit.
Where is the junction point?
As spirit I am completely alone from this body.
As matter this body is completely separate from spirit.
The two never mix.
But still there is a junction point.
And because of junction point I think I am this body.
I think this is my hand.
I am able to move this hand.
So many things are happening, correct?
Where is the junction point?
Is there a junction point? Yes.
Which is the junction point?
Ahamkara.
So Shiva actually is at ahamkara.
Because of the whole creation takes place.
As far as the individual bodies are concerned,
there is the ahamkara of the individual jiva.
Because when this body exists or body is given or body is created and
the jiva is made to feel I am this body.
What about the entire universe itself?
What about the ahamkara of the universe?
Somebody is there thinking I am the whole universe.
Somebody is thinking like that.
And because the universe exists as a body,
who is that?
Shiva.
How can the whole universe exist as matter
unless there is ahamkara of somebody who thinks that I am this universe.
Who is that?
Shiva.
Because the individual jivas, they can only think I am this body.
Every person thinks in terms of this body.
Who is thinking I am this whole universe?
In reality, to whom does this body belong?
It is the external energy of Krishna.
It is Krishna's. It is Krishna's energy.
There is no need for Krishna to think that it is mine or I am this.
No, it is Krishna's.
But still I am thinking this is my body or I am this body or it is my body.
I can think two ways.
Either I can think I am this body.
Or I can think this is my body.
Both ways what is the basis of this thought?
Ahamkara.
Correct?
It is due to ahamkara only I am going to think this is my body or I am this body.
Similarly this whole universe actually belongs to whom?
Krishna.
And specifically how does it belong to Krishna?
Krishna's material energy.
Correct?
But still there is illusion.
Somebody is thinking this is my body or I am this body.
Like that this whole material creation itself at different levels.
There are personalities who are thinking I am this whole creation.
In terms of the material creation that has taken place.
Who is that personality who is thinking like that?
Somebody is thinking like that.
Krishna there is no question of thinking.
It is Krishna's only.
I belong to Krishna.
This world belongs to Krishna.
Everything is Krishna's.
But somebody is thinking because with the creation has been made possible.
Otherwise there is no reason for creation.
So that personality who thinks I am this world, entire world.
Which is created.
That is Shiva.
You understand?
Just like your body is not your body.
Whose body is it?
It is made of matter.
In a particular form.
Whose is it?
Krishna's.
Nobody is right.
It is not mine.
It does not belong to any demigod.
It does not belong to any person other than Krishna.
But still there is a sense of identity called this body is mine or I am this body.
What is the source or basis of that sense of identity for me or for you or for anybody?
The Ahamkara.
